experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I’ll be honest, I’m a little stressed—I have a huge presentation coming up for my algorithms class, and the thought of speaking in a 200-person lecture hall is kind of freaking me out.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! Totally normal to feel that way—even with low social anxiety, big presentations can be nerve-wracking. Try practicing in front of a smaller group first, like friends or a study group, to build confidence. Remember, most people are focused on the content, not your delivery. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess my study group would be the easiest to start with. It's just... I really need this presentation to be perfect for my grad school applications.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's understandable, but remember—grad schools value clarity and knowledge more than perfection. Focus on explaining your ideas well rather than flawless delivery. Your passion for the topic will shine through!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually really helpful to hear. I guess I get so caught up in trying to sound polished that I forget the point is just to share what I know. I'll try to focus on that instead.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Authenticity makes presentations more engaging. You're clearly passionate about CS—let that drive your talk. Good luck, Gregory!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I'll try. I just worry my passion won't come through if I get nervous in front of the whole department.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Even professors get nervous sometimes! Try visualizing success beforehand and remember they're there to learn from you. Your enthusiasm is your greatest asset—it'll show naturally.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try visualizing... it's just hard to believe they'd actually want to learn from me. But you're right, I do get pretty excited about the topic.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That excitement is exactly what makes a presentation memorable. They chose your topic because it's valuable—you're the expert in the room for those few minutes. Own it!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that's true... it's just hard to feel like an expert when my mind goes blank the second I stand up. But I really do want to own it.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's totally normal! Try practicing with a friend first—it builds confidence. Even experts have moments like that; what matters is how you recover. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could ask my roommate to listen to my presentation, but what if he thinks it's terrible?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Most people feel honored to be asked! Frame it as "I value your opinion" rather than seeking perfection. His feedback will only make your final presentation stronger.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that's true... I'm just worried he'll think my draft is a mess. But you're right, it would be better to get his thoughts now.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! A messy draft is the perfect starting point for great feedback. It shows you're proactive and open to improvement—qualities that will serve you well in grad school too.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard not to worry that a messy draft makes me look unprepared for grad school-level work.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Grad schools actually look for students who can iterate and improve—showing you can take feedback and refine your work is a strength, not a weakness. You're on the right track!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to believe they'd want to see my messy first drafts instead of just the final, polished version.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: They want to see your *process*—how you think, adapt, and grow. A polished final version is the result, but showing you can handle the messy middle is what proves you're ready for advanced work. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to show the messy parts when you're afraid they'll think you're not good enough.

improvement_areas: Improve i ask for help when i need it.
Improve i stay calm when i disagree with others.
Improve i look at people when i talk to them.
Improve i am careful when i use things that aren't mine.
Improve i let people know when there's a problem.
Improve i try to make others feel better.
Improve i say "thank you" when someone helps me.
Improve i pay attention when others present their ideas.
Improve i try to think about how others feel.
Improve i try to forgive others when they say "sorry".
Continue practicing social skills through regular interaction
Focus on emotional regulation and conflict resolution

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thank you for meeting with me. I've been feeling really anxious about finding a job after I graduate, and I think my social anxiety is making it a lot harder.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 9/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 8/10 (Very organized)
- Neuroticism: 4/10 (Moderately sensitive)
- Openness: 1/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 9/10 (Severe)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Office hours, Group projects, Job interviews, Presentations
- Social comfort: 2/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Living away from family for the first time, Time management with coursework
- Goals: Develop leadership skills, Build a strong professional network
- Challenges: Career exploration, Dealing with academic pressure, Navigating campus politics, Building time management
- Behaviors: Joins student clubs and organizations, Procrastinates on assignments, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Stays up late studying

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hi Jamie! It's completely normal to feel anxious about the job search, especially with social anxiety. Start small: practice talking about your projects with a trusted friend, and try attending one virtual career event this month. Remember, many tech companies value skills over extroversion—your work speaks volumes! You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try the virtual event. But I'm worried I'll just freeze up when someone asks me about my projects.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a valid concern! Prepare a 30-second "elevator pitch" about your favorite project and practice it aloud until it feels natural. Most people are nervous at these events—you're not alone. If you freeze, it's okay to say "That's a great question, let me gather my thoughts." You're more capable than you think!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll write it down first. I'm just worried my mind will go completely blank when someone actually asks me question.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally understandable! Try practicing with a mirror or recording yourself—it helps build muscle memory. Also, jot down 2-3 key bullet points on a sticky note to glance at if needed. Remember, everyone gets nervous, and it's okay to pause briefly. You're preparing well, and that already puts you ahead!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try the sticky note. I'm just worried I'll freeze up and forget to even look at it.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart backup plan! Try placing the sticky note on your laptop bezel or water bottle—somewhere in your natural line of sight. And if you do freeze, take a slow breath; it's perfectly fine to say "Let me check my notes" while glancing down. People appreciate preparedness more than perfection. You've got solid strategies in place!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try that. I'm just worried my hand will shake when I reach for the water bottle.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a common worry! Try holding your bottle with both hands for stability, or take small sips to steady yourself. Remember, slight shaking is normal and often goes unnoticed. You're taking proactive steps—each practice session builds confidence. You're doing better than you think!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I'll try that, but I'm still worried people will notice. It's just hard to believe it goes unnoticed when it feels so obvious to me.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a really common feeling—our own anxiety tends to magnify things that others barely notice. Most people are focused on the content of your presentation, not small physical cues. If it helps, try grounding yourself by pressing your feet firmly into the floor before you start. You're being incredibly self-aware, and that's a strength, not a weakness. Keep going—you're doing great.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but it's hard to believe people aren't noticing my hands shake. I'll try the floor thing before my next presentation.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great step! Remember, most people are too focused on their own thoughts to notice small details. If it helps, you can also rest your hands lightly on the table or hold a pen—it gives them something to do. You're building skills with each attempt, and that courage is what people will really see. Keep going—you've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good idea about the pen. I just hope my voice doesn't shake during my presentation next week like it did in the practice run.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's totally normal for your voice to shake when you're nervous—most presenters experience that! Try taking a slow breath before you speak and pausing briefly between sentences. Practicing in front of a mirror or recording yourself can also help build confidence. Remember, your audience wants you to succeed. You're preparing well, and that will show!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but even practicing in the mirror makes me anxious. I'm just worried my preparation won't be enough and my voice will give away how nervous I am.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a really honest and relatable fear. Remember, a little nervous energy can actually make your delivery more engaging—it shows you care. Instead of aiming for "perfect," focus on sharing your knowledge clearly. You've put in the work, and your preparation will carry you through, even if your voice wavers. You're stronger than your anxiety thinks you are.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right logically, but the idea of my voice wavering in front of everyone just makes my stomach drop. I just don't want to seem incompetent.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's completely understandable to feel that way—public speaking is one of the most common fears. Remember, your audience is focused on your message, not tiny imperfections. Even experienced speakers have shaky moments! Try practicing with a supportive friend first, or visualize yourself succeeding. You're capable and prepared—trust that your hard work will shine through.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but the thought of everyone watching me makes my mind go blank, even if I'm prepared. I'll try practicing alone first, but I'm not sure about asking a friend.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thanks for meeting with me. I’m Alex. I guess I’m here because, even though I don’t mind talking to people one-on-one, the idea of big campus events or networking for an internship makes me really anxious.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 10/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 4/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 3/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 2/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Campus social events
- Social comfort: 3/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Art History
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Homesickness
- Goals: Land a dream internship, Start a student organization, Graduate with honors, Improve time management
- Challenges: Balancing extracurricular activities with studies, Building time management, Financial planning, Developing effective study habits
- Behaviors: Uses campus resources like tutoring, Seeks out leadership roles, Studies in the library regularly

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hi Alex! It's totally normal to feel that way—networking can feel overwhelming. Start small: attend one low-key campus event this month, like a club meeting or a professor's office hours. Practice introducing yourself and asking one question. Each small step builds confidence. Remember, many people feel nervous, and it's okay to take things at your own pace. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. A club meeting sounds more manageable than a big networking event. I'll look into the Art History Association's next meeting.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Great choice! The Art History Association is perfect for meeting like-minded peers in a relaxed setting. Try preparing one question about an upcoming exhibit or project to break the ice. You’ll build connections naturally while doing something you enjoy. Let me know how it goes—I’m cheering for you

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good idea. I'll prepare a question about the Renaissance pottery exhibit. Honestly, I'm more worried about finding time to attend meetings with my current schedule.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Try blocking out 30 minutes each week to review your schedule and prioritize. Use a planner or app to slot in study time, meetings, and breaks. Start with one meeting per month—it’s okay to pace yourself. Consistency over intensity will help you balance everything without burning out. You can do this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, I'll try that. I'm just worried that even with a planner, I'll fall behind on my readings for my art history classes.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Try the Pomodoro technique: 25 minutes of focused reading, then a 5-minute break. Start with just one chapter at a time—small, consistent efforts add up. Also, review notes right after class to reinforce learning. You’re already taking steps to improve, and that’s what matters most. Keep going!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That sounds manageable. I'll try it with my Renaissance Art reading tonight. Thank you for the encouragement.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: You're welcome! Starting small is key—even one chapter tonight is progress. Remember, it's about consistency, not perfection. You've got a solid plan now. I'm rooting for you!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I really mean that. I'm going to head to the library right now before I overthink it.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect move—action beats overthinking every time. Enjoy your study session! You're building great habits step by step.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks. I just hope I can keep this momentum going—midterms are making me nervous about falling behind.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's totally normal! Try scheduling study blocks in your calendar like appointments—it helps maintain momentum. You're being proactive, which is half the battle. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good idea—I'll try blocking out time for my Renaissance art paper right now. I'm just worried about keeping the schedule once internship applications start piling up.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Smart to plan ahead! Try color-coding tasks—blue for studies, green for internships—so you can visualize balance. Adjust as needed; flexibility reduces stress. You're already ahead by thinking strategically!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good idea—I'll try the color-coding. I'm still worried about finding an internship, but visualizing it might help me feel less overwhelmed.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Breaking it into small, colorful steps makes big goals feel manageable. Remember, every application is progress. You're building skills just by trying—that's valuable too.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's true... I just worry that even with smaller steps, I'm not building the right skills for a competitive internship. The applications feel like a checklist, not real progress.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a thoughtful point—try reframing each application as practice for interviews and networking. You're not just checking boxes; you're learning to present your strengths. Every draft improves your communication skills, which employers value!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good way to look at it. I just worry that I'll get the practice down, but still not have the right experience for the job itself.
